Award.AwardTitle: The NCC Math Science Learning Community

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Northampton Community College's Math Science Learning Community is creating two Faculty Learning Communities (FLCs), one on NCC's Monroe Campus and one on NCC's Bethlehem Campus. Each FLC is developing a sustainable plan for increasing the use of evidence-based practices that have been proven in both the national literature and in NCC practice to positively impact student success. The FLCs are exploring inquiry-based learning, experiential learning, and modified STEM student learning communities in math and science gateway courses. FLCs are each developing a plan that reflects the unique institutional culture of each campus and presenting the plans to college administration for implementation. Each FLC member is working on an individual project to improve learning in a STEM gateway course that he or she is teaching, and the group members are collectively sharing their knowledge and accomplishments with the wider college and STEM community.

Community colleges face unique barriers to scaling up high impact strategies. Many have not yet adopted an institution-wide culture of evidence-based decision making. Moreover, the heavy teaching loads of community college faculty inhibit their ability to research and implement reforms, yet they are the very group who must implement the reforms. The change strategies being implemented include faculty learning communities and strategic planning. Lessons learned from this project are impacting the outcomes of nearly half the nation's STEM students by adding to the body of knowledge on the effect of increased use of inquiry based learning, experiential learning, and learning communities on student learning, especially for members of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to learn how to successfully increase the use by science, technology, engineering, and mathematics instructors of instructional approaches that research has shown increase student learning.

As a result of this project we learned that a very effective method for increasing the use of these practices is to ask the participating instructors to try one of the supported practices that had not previously used. We supported experiential learning (undergraduate research, service learning where students work with the community on a project, job shadowing, and internships), inquiry-based learning (students learn by working in small groups on open problems requiring understanding of the discipline), modified learning communities (students in different classes work collaboratively on a common problem, sharing how the different disciplines can help understand and solve the problem), and assessment for learning (using assessment techniques to help students learn concepts). To make this work we had to provide professional development on each practice. Knowing they would be trying one of the practices meant that the instructors were motivated to learn the new practice. Our research showed that success in using the practice changed beliefs and often resulted in expanded use of the practice. Accountability was an important component of this engagement of instructors. Because they knew that they were expected to report on what they had done and the extent of success they had, all participants did try a new instructional practice and did reflect on how they were teaching. Our surveys showed that those instructors involved in this project used significantly more effective practices in their courses than those not involved in the project.

We also learned the importance of providing support during the implementation of the new practice. All participating instructors were active members of a learning community consisting of instructors and student services personnel involved with the project. The learning communities met every three weeks. Topics included team building, professional development on each practice, and sharing of drafts of projects which were revised based on feedback, sharing of results, and developing assessments. Also, we learned that mentors can be very valuable, especially for part-time instructors, to assist them in designing and developing new instructional materials and designing evaluation instruments. Mentors can also help instructors avoid mistakes the mentors made when they first tried a new practice.

A third lesson learned was that we must address the barriers to change, if we want to significantly increase the use of best practices. At community colleges this means addressing barriers to change among both full-time and part-time instructors. A major barrier to change is the time needed for professional development to learn how to use a best practice. One way to deal with this barrier is to create “ready to use” materials that can easily be adapted by instructors. Many instructors told us they were concerned that if they actively engaged their students in their learning, they would not have enough time to address all of the topics in their course. We addressed this concern by sharing personal experiences as well as research that showed more learning without a decrease in the amount of topics covered. Part-time instructors were especially concerned that they would receive a bad evaluation from the administration as well as poor student ratings if they tried a best practice. We are addressing this barrier by having the administration emphasize that they want instructors to use practices that actively engage students and revising the student evaluation instruments.

Another important lesson learned was the importance of collaborating with partners to increase the opportunities for our students to learn by doing. More community college students can do undergraduate research if we partner with research universities and colleges with grants designed to give students undergraduate research experience. More students can get internships in their field, if we have someone locating internships. More students will work with local non-profits, if we assist instructors in finding non-profits with needs that match a particular discipline.

Finally, if we are going to be successful in getting more instructors using best instructional practices we have to change the culture at the college. This includes changing the reward system so instructors are rewarded for using best practices rather than penalized for their use. It also includes providing technology, classrooms, and academic and student services that support the instructors as they strive to increase learning.
